The Caribbean coast of Nicaragua is truly one-of-a-kind. Once a haven for pirates and contra rebels, it is located on the furthest edge of the country's Autonomous Regions. There are six distinct ethnicities and five languages that make up this cultural rondon.

There are some rural places in the Caribbean where people might not speak Spanish. Common languages along the Caribbean side of Nicaragua are in ascending order of speakers: Rama Miskito and caribbean creole English. as Caribbean English can be hard to understand (almost impossible to most to whom English is a secondary language) Spanish might still be your best bet. More developed places often have a lot of recent immigrants from Spanish speaking parts of the country. Especially in tourism-related professions
Transport is mostly by boat or on awful roads. Most domestic flights go into and out of this part of the country. The road from El Rama to Managua however is one of the best in the country.

Depending on where you are food ranges from very basic Nicaraguan fare to truly mouth-watering seafood and coconut-extravaganza. A special treat is ron don (from English run down) a fish and coconut stew that takes time and expertise to prepare so order well in advance.
This part of the country is not unaffected by drug traffic so crime is more common than on the Pacific side. However, with a basic level of caution you should be safe.
